intro: Silene nocturna subsp. decipiens, commonly known as the moonflower, is a species of flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its large, white, night-blooming flowers that emit a sweet fragrance, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branching. Silene nocturna subsp. decipiens is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its showy flowers and ecological importance in desert ecosystems.
